topic.title: Possible to delete ZeroID?
topic.body:
For privacy, most websites (e.g. reddit on clearnet) allow you to delete your account if needed. 
Is this possible on ZeroNet?

topic.title: Brainstorm: Increasing anonymity on ZeroNet
topic.body:
Zeronet is an amazing project. However, it isn't exactly built with total anonymity/privacy in mind.

Some ideas I've been thinking about...

Problems:

* ZeroID is a centralized service, you can host your own instance, but then people have to use it.
* ZeroIDs cannot be deleted or renamed.

Possible solutions:

* A) Create a Zite with shared/throwaway ZeroID. Users will upload their private keys (not for security obviously, just for throwaway accounts), and share them with others to use. The more people that use them, the greater the anonymity (mixing principle).
* B) Get username cloaks/delete options built into ZeroNet

---

Problems:
* WebGL, Angular JS, and other modern javascript "features" are very bad for anonymity due to their vast browser fingerprinting capabilities

* Hotlinking to images, clearnet pages, and even CloudFlare has already been occurring on some ZeroNet zites. 

Possible solutions:

* A) Convince zites not to use aggressive javascript where it's not needed, and not to host content outside of ZeroNet

* B) Create a "content-filter" for ZeroNet the blocks aggressive APIs and any outbound connections that are not to 127.0.0.1:43110 for security reasons.

Problems:

* Zeronet's "GeoIP database" (found in the sidebar menu by swiping the "zero" to the left") shows your exact location even if using Tor on the WebGL earth

Possible solutions:

* Determine if this is in fact an IP leak, and if so get it fixed ASAP. Since --tor mode should not leak IP to clearweb.

----

Might have missed some things, but that's what I've noticed so far. Thoughts?

1_1PiXrhT1UjMZmJc5WFhfUxourdfapeHJ8o.body:
It's good that people are fleeing Google, but DuckDuckGo is still centralized by nature. It's hosted on [Amazon Cloud](http://www.zdnet.com/article/no-privacy-on-amazons-cloud-drive/), and they partner with Yahoo (who is now owned by the infamous [Verizon](https://www.eff.org/deeplinks/2014/11/verizon-x-uidh) network).

Since Searx is federated, and capable of searching DuckDuckGo/StartPage, it's the better option currently.
https://github.com/asciimoo/searx/wiki/Searx-instances

There's also a purely decentralized search engine - [YaCy](http://yacy.net/en/index.html), but not enough people are running it to keep results accurate.

> [cosmologica](#comment_14_1PiXrhT1UjMZmJc5WFhfUxourdfapeHJ8o): Yacy work so for that I can download search options, but I cannot add something to it. So far my experience.

I *hate* YouTube, but here's a good tutorial for adding sites to YaCy: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=UUAylWYqzac

> [apwrokiqorwq](#comment_1_1Bk2heJQnpwHvQLSt5s4PZc9pdjH6MtqHE): Google will grow, Google will rise, Google will conquer. [...]

Pretty sure you mean Amazon. They're quickly growing to be much more powerful than Google.
* [Amazon Is the Scariest Part of The CIA's New Amazon​ Cloud Storage](http://blackbag.gawker.com/amazon-is-the-scariest-part-of-the-cias-new-amazon-clo-1605847721)

Imagine the data power of Google, but with the physical presence of Amazon. We're talking 24/7 surveillance, drones, the ability to monitor nearly all your financial transactions, and the ability to block you from getting products. They've successfully shutdown many box stores, so you only have one place to go.

4_1AWSA7oG2qrhWYgeSiJtDHCwc2KvyR7ijs.body: Really depends on the cipher, assuming it is just hex values, you can convert hex-to-text using the [Cryptii](https://cryptii.com/hexadecimal/text) web-tool.

1_1Bk2heJQnpwHvQLSt5s4PZc9pdjH6MtqHE.body: Excellent idea. [Looks like someone is already on it](http://127.0.0.1:43110/1GWKbh1vtmccqQBZNaR3xBZ18WYVzxuD1z/?Post:3:Git+over+ZeroNet)

1_1DiRWRFXcVgQQ75cXnAG2pyxxjGo2VaH5.body:
> [obiwanzanobi](#comment_26_1LUy9iAxeWsj1DP5L8V17Yb2vo87FucjgD): I think if you uninstall and reinstall zeronet you might be able to, but I'm not sure.

I think that would allow you to create a new identity, but that still leaves your old account and all it's info floating out here - abandoned.

> [ixhb5a7vwvdgimjx](#comment_3_18fLf6bqfzvGLvMA2DrEmDxiqvnAWyN6dv): You can remove your content from sites, but due to the way ZeroNet works, anyone can save old copies of your data once they are published. ZeroNet is designed for persistency. If you are looking to delete stuff you are in the wrong place.

It's possible to edit/overwrite comments, so it's confusing to me there's not a "delete account" option. Yes, some data would be hanging around, but typically speaking it would be wiped as soon as the peers update. Such an option could exist.

> [ixhb5a7vwvdgimjx](#comment_4_18fLf6bqfzvGLvMA2DrEmDxiqvnAWyN6dv): But again, it does not prevent anyone determined in the slightest from acquiring your data, so I can't say I see the point in doing it. [...]

The same could be said for Reddit. They store the information permanently. However, it becomes unindexed from search engines and crawlers moving forward, which helps some.

2_1JTtwMPZ5mKaF6S1wAPzZ8SmZTgTygz5Rb.body: I would be interested in this too, but I suppose if you use Tor Browser it mitigates the threat partially. There are actually a few images posted around that are hosted externally as well. (Which risks an IP leak)

3_13aB79mzuRLgDYzQthn9wzycjw77WyDXh6.body:

https://bugs.freedesktop.org/show_bug.cgi?id=16891#c46

1_14675V7vYqpfKSrPyybCNyAvUNpm7LdaxC.body:
> [zeropyro](#comment_1_1KsFe6vgVpNFCNTQDQryrcQYySkAbFLXCV): Zeronet can not seed you site through the Tor network!... The problem its not possible to seed or make changes a site as publisher (server admin) anonim way through Tor.

Per [this github ticket](https://github.com/HelloZeroNet/ZeroNet/issues/873#issuecomment-289996222) it's actually possible to upload the initial zite through Tor and behind a NAT, so as long as you have a working peer that is not behind the NAT. This can also be any of the open zeronet proxy.

1_17X6HcuDcCF3nTTGoCTjZTHFdHV67f3Xqb.body: As far as I know it is not easily (if at all?) possible to impersonate another person's ZeroID.

e.g. zeronet.py --fileserver_port 8080

Complete list of args: https://github.com/HelloZeroNet/ZeroNet/blob/master/src/Config.py

Food rations are available for [qualifying](https://www.cbsnews.com/news/china-communist-party-social-credit-score-silence-critics/) [UIDAI](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Unique_Identification_Authority_of_India)'s from [Amazon](https://www.theatlantic.com/technology/archive/2014/07/the-details-about-the-cias-deal-with-amazon/374632/). Unauthorized access to non-government sanctioned speech is [prohibited](https://torrentfreak.com/india-orders-blackout-of-vimeo-the-pirate-bay-and-more-120504/) and [innaccessible](https://www.usatoday.com/story/tech/nation-now/2016/09/21/revealed-north-koreas-internet-only-has-28-websites/90781778/)...*

1_19QUk6wDdk8hSNPGa85GtsZD5yApSzPem6.body:
Assuming Tor and ZeroNet are running...

To "torify" standard Firefox, navigate to:
Edit --> Preferences --> Advanced --> Network --> Settings --> Manual proxy config --> 
> **Socks Host:** 127.0.0.1 **Port:** 9050
Make sure "Proxy DNS when using SOCKS v5" is checked. Press "OK".

Under "General", Set homepage as "http://127.0.0.1:43110". Now when you start Firefox it will navigate to ZeroNet and use Tor by default.

Keep in mind this isn't recommended for anonymity since Tor Browser has additional security patches that do not come with Firefox.

8_18Cxdyc2FEuswoXnBkrAfCkM2Yu1p4NjcR.body: Not too bad of an idea, so as long as it isn't compulsory. Older computers would suffer immensely from running miners on pages. That's not considering, if the idea took off, just how many of the open tabs would all be fighting over CPU power for mining.

1_1ACc4pa2pJam33SkSE1zF1seF3LQKWR24v.body:
Easiest way: Make a backup of your ZeroNet directory, and run it off a portable drive. 

As far as syncing them individually, maybe something like [Syncthing](https://syncthing.net/), but I've not tried it.

2_1ACc4pa2pJam33SkSE1zF1seF3LQKWR24v.body: Loads properly here. Nice looking Zite.

Re: Zites that host external content. I agree. ZeroNet should implement some sort of cross-site request blocking for clearnet. 

So far, I've found ZeroVoat, ZeroName (perhaps most critically), and Zoogle all link to clearweb. That's not good for offline mode or privacy.

2_14LA8sy5pK11V4azVA9wTmMpu1VYCqT822.body:
> [sub](#comment_1_14LA8sy5pK11V4azVA9wTmMpu1VYCqT822): This was lifted from TechDirt - Just wanted to put this article here because it's worth reading and understanding the importance of THIS platform.

The problem is, ISPs/Governments/Gateways can be used to throttle or block ZeroNet too. We will need to support some form of mesh protocol to keep moving forward, be it cjdns or something else.

1_1BXrm8Bwf3e4DPasJ5L3txhjqhmwhcVdtm.body:
It can be done, but [Tor recommends against it](https://blog.torproject.org/bittorrent-over-tor-isnt-good-idea). 

[I2P](https://thetinhat.com/tutorials/darknets/i2p.html) is the better option for anonymous torrenting.

One of the I2P sites to get you going: torrentfinder.i2p

Another option would be [Tribler](https://www.tribler.org/), but it's not considered anonymous.

2_1H5UJ7LneToGqYqJ9fbLnu1Ko2pxTpchof.body:
I'm personally of the impression that both Congress and the FCC are incapable of keeping a "neutral" network by over-regulating it with legal terms they themselves do not understand. The only way we can really win this battle is through technology and boycotts of corporations.

Also: The FCC **will** leak your name and address into the public record. Keep that in mind when sending them petitions.

> [jayofthezero](#comment_8_16nArdxrSaNThNp83kL8E6NLL9WD98iUne): You'd have more success suing the FCC or getting him replaced than actually changing his goals.

Even getting him replaced wouldn't help much, the corporate cronyism is too strong. Check out [The FCC Revolving Door](http://127.0.0.1:43110/1J1c7eML6uMwDU4uiKbKRxoqxGP6WMFMvb/index.html?view:topic+topic_id=1DiRWRFXcVgQQ75cXnAG2pyxxjGo2VaH5topic1).

> [jayofthezero](#comment_10_16nArdxrSaNThNp83kL8E6NLL9WD98iUne): Many locations in the US are monopolized by single ISPs so there is no free market.

Agreed, although this is usually due to government sanctioned monopolies. See also: Zoning Laws / Corporate "Subsidies". By allowing big business to suck off tax payers through corporate welfare, we've created this mess. It's hardly a free market. They've also setup their barriers and more laws to keep would-be new ISPs out. It's the same reason Amazon approves of an internet sales tax.

https://www.forbes.com/sites/realspin/2013/09/04/amazon-can-support-the-internet-sales-tax-because-amazon-is-exempt/

> [jayofthezero](#comment_10_16nArdxrSaNThNp83kL8E6NLL9WD98iUne): so now what are those people going to use to access the internet?

Use [Calyx](https://www.calyxinstitute.org/)?

7_1H5UJ7LneToGqYqJ9fbLnu1Ko2pxTpchof.body:
> What do you think about this idle though of mine? Good idea? Do you have any better ideas that doesn’t involve going back to religious dogma and shaming people for wanting sex?


Due to the “one flesh” aspect of marriage, the need for oneness and harmony in marriage, and the lack of any real need for polygamy, it's better to remain monogamous.  In view of the problems it causes (jealousy, strife, contention, broken families, etc.), it is no wonder that polygamy was unknown among the Jews after the Babylonian exile, and monogamy was the rule even among the Greeks and Romans by New Testament times.

There’s a reason why the government has never permitted relatives to marry, nor upheld the legality of polygamy... Traditional marriage is the naturally and scientifically verifiable familial foundation (defined gender roles: woman/wife/mother-man/husband/father). On what grounds is THIS essential biological/foundational model overridden? Ultimately, “government has a compelling interest in a legal record of procreation (this is further indicated by the doctrine of presumed paternity), and in creating a lasting environment where children will thrive. The fact that one must obtain a court order to divorce and the existence of tax-based incentives for marriage are other effects of the government’s interest in marriage.” A stable and successful nuclear family dynamic has always been the central barometer indicative of a thriving country.

> [iyogo887vyg87oy8](#comment_11_1H5UJ7LneToGqYqJ9fbLnu1Ko2pxTpchof): First of all, I'm advocating polyamory (sex with more than one person) as opposed to polygamy (multiple marriage). [...]

How well did that work in the 1960's? [Not very well](http://womenspowerbook.org/sexual-revolution-std-clinic-herpes-aids-warts.htm) health wise...

8_1H5UJ7LneToGqYqJ9fbLnu1Ko2pxTpchof.body: I've tried ZeroNet tethered to a pretty slow phone connection, worked rather well. This is the internet of the future!

1_1PbHPT2BbYmTiM1SP278hAGmR23eJoMwGG.body: I think projects like ZeroNet will help, especially once we get LAN/cjdns support. In situations where the internet has been completely cut-off, we will need to rely on mesh networking to communicate.

1_1KRueLENohFTeiAzfbr1s7VMfYBgcmm1Ur.body: Whatever the heck [ZeroNet coins](https://bitcointalk.org/index.php?topic=2207595.msg22227315#msg22227315) are, they don't have anything to do with ZeroNet apart from the name. The fact they are pre-mined sounds sketchy to me. Basically worthless, but amusing nonetheless.

> [vajag88](#comment_4_1P9VFgUn4ov1WCAy3xhSWHCiFR9hjSwdrT): I got Android Bitkoin Wallet - it doesn't see my email. That's the reason I'm here. But local email no way too. Confused.

Use the open-source [Electrum](https://electrum.org) wallet for BTCs. You should never need to give an e-mail address or any other personal information for a wallet.

11_1H5UJ7LneToGqYqJ9fbLnu1Ko2pxTpchof.body:
People follow the latest trend, and the path of least resistance. I assume their logic goes like this:

1) Do all the hot girls and my friends use it? 
2) Does it require me to do something besides give all my personal data away (I have *nothing* to hide).
e.g. I refuse to download anything unless it's a file sharing client with tonz of warez or a big signup bonus.

Since ZeroNet is not as widely used, and it doesn't offer hot chicks, warez, or bonuses for downloading, they crawl back to Tinder and Facebook. This tech is better, but the average user doesn't care. It's sad.

> [iyogo887vyg87oy8](#comment_26_1H5UJ7LneToGqYqJ9fbLnu1Ko2pxTpchof): I put google back into my phone (location was being screwy for a reason or other) and i decided to have a look at tinder again.. somebody super liked me but their face is all blurry im not sure i like them back /s :P

Heh. Maybe someone should start a ZeroTend dating app, that would bring in the users.

> [flappyearz](#comment_68_1QEfmMwKVxgR4rkREbdJYjgUmF3Zy8pwHt): Your choice. Must be very adventurous reasons I'm sure. I trust you being smarter than Snowden and the bunch of the security researchers out there. :-]

Up until recently, it required using Gapps. In addition to that, you are required to have a phone number (bad for metadata), and to register (also bad for metadata), to use Signal's [OWS server](https://github.com/WhisperSystems/Signal-Android/issues/6620) (bad for privacy). I appreciate Moxie's advances in encryption, but he fails entirely on anonymity and privacy. Would no longer recommend that app when we have Riot, Tox, and Tor Messenger at our disposal.

> [anonymouslogin](#comment_77_17AMQVbBa12XB3xFWKDnP2dCEx92TaiY7X): Please sirrah, might I request a link?

https://trac.torproject.org/projects/tor/wiki/doc/TorMessenger#Downloads

2_1EMDKkZzS2ztrvcsUmzFkifjMWKFu73zCs.body:
As far as I know they stay there forever until you delete them. Even if you to delete them, they will stay as long as there are peers. 

Taking [Zarcade](http://127.0.0.1:43110/1EwpsssQGBrC2EZeYvxeQQoQbKNGivwDi4/) as an example, not enough peers were able to keep the games online even though the site itself is still floating around partially.

> [deadfwd2017](#comment_8_1EMDKkZzS2ztrvcsUmzFkifjMWKFu73zCs): ...The UI needs to be rewritten to hide all that then and have them auto drop after 6 months for example...

Not really, the entire point of ZeroNet is p2p hosting. Zites are resistant to takedown and centralization, so any visitor also becomes a host. If such an autodrop were proposed, we'd have tons of dead links and bitrot.

8_13aB79mzuRLgDYzQthn9wzycjw77WyDXh6.body:
Hopefully soon.

I wonder how feasible it might be to run ZeroNet off a [dead drop](https://deaddrops.com/). In theory, the content would exist properly on the drive until it finally reaches the internet and resyncs. There is still the risk of usb malware, and physical snooping, however...

When all else fails there's [Briar](https://briarproject.org/how-it-works.html) for nearby contacts.

Slightly off-topic, but for anyone who needs to get on I2P: 
http://127.0.0.1:43110/1uPLoaDwKzP6MCGoVzw48r4pxawRBdmQc/data/users/1DiRWRFXcVgQQ75cXnAG2pyxxjGo2VaH5/1507814925-I2P_0.9.3.1.zip

The zip includes the reseed which is apparently blocked by the Great Firewall.

Everyone is dropping NFC at the moment, Google announced [they are dropping it](https://www.nfcworld.com/2017/10/02/354913/google-drops-nfc-smart-unlock-due-extremely-low-usage/) in some capacity well.

HotKnot sounds like a privacy risk.

> “It utilizes the physics of a capacitive touch screen, such that the transmitting grid in the screen of one phone can interact with the receiving grid in a second when they are in close proximity (less than 1 centimeter).” - [Forget NFC, Hotknot makes you transfer and share files using your smartphone’s touchscreen](http://www.dignited.com/13695/forget-nfc-hotknot-makes-you-transfer-and-share-files-using-your-smartphones-touchscreen/)

2_17H8EGEoNF1z2AXFtXmBQJLHTmh7gMGzzS.body:
Taking a purely hands-off approach still leaves you vulnerable to mobocracy, and those who lead the mob. 

> "Democracy will soon degenerate into an anarchy; such an anarchy that every man will do what is right in his own eyes and no man's life or property or reputation or liberty will be secure, and every one of these will soon mould itself into a system of subordination of all the moral virtues and intellectual abilities, all the powers of wealth, beauty, wit, and science, to the wanton pleasures, the capricious will, and the execrable cruelty of one or a very few." -- John Adams, An Essay on Man's Lust for Power (1763)

> [marxistleninist](#comment_8_1626jBiKnxjqtA1UJrSQEF1zWk3CMHZrLR): Crowds are also generally smarter than individuals, calling it mob rule is an excuse for elitism you capitalist apologist. Since when did class exploiters have you interests at heart - answer never.

"Wisdom of the crowd" is a rather illusive term, and crowd manipulation is fairly easy to accomplish.

> Suppose you’re making the important decision to marry. Would you like the decision about whom you marry to be made through a democratic procedure where what the majority of Americans think determines whom you marry? How about using the democratic process to decide what we have for Thanksgiving dinner? Majority rule determines whether everyone has turkey, or ham, or duck, or capon. Once the vote is taken and, say, turkey wins, everyone is obliged to serve turkey... That’s one important problem with democracy: *It creates an aura of moral legitimacy for acts that would otherwise be considered tyranny.* ~ [Do We Want Democracy](http://capitalismmagazine.com/2002/06/do-we-want-democracy/)

...

> Life and happiness in this life under any political system directly depend upon how much our individuality (versus the crowd) is retained and to what extent we throw off manipulated illusions...
>
> The more one’s mind is immersed into the crowd, of course, the more one loses his individuality and independence of thought. The more we become a part of the crowd, the more dependent we become on authority. And the more dependent we become, the more defensive we are when presented with new information contrary to “conventional wisdom.” Simply stated, the crowd syndrome inoculates us against reality...
>
> By virtue of the fact that the elite (government and the banksters) has the power to create money, all wealth flows away from the producers to the nonproducers. Modern money (nonsubstance) expropriates wealth. Translated, this simply means that one class of people perpetually steals from the other class. This makes them natural enemies. ~ [Personal Liberty](https://personalliberty.com/the-politicians-and-the-manipulated-crowd/)

1509087257_1CGP23WuLE1DHpiAyGuSoNrNzabKv.body:
[Tor](http://127.0.0.1:43110/1uPLoaDwKzP6MCGoVzw48r4pxawRBdmQc/data/users/1DiRWRFXcVgQQ75cXnAG2pyxxjGo2VaH5/1507899341-tox-clients.zip) with meek bridges, [I2P](http://127.0.0.1:43110/1uPLoaDwKzP6MCGoVzw48r4pxawRBdmQc/data/users/1DiRWRFXcVgQQ75cXnAG2pyxxjGo2VaH5/1507814925-I2P_0.9.3.1.zip), shadowsocks, [tox](http://127.0.0.1:43110/1uPLoaDwKzP6MCGoVzw48r4pxawRBdmQc/data/users/1DiRWRFXcVgQQ75cXnAG2pyxxjGo2VaH5/1507899341-tox-clients.zip).

When downloading any of said tools, use official sources to [verify](https://www.torproject.org/docs/verifying-signatures.html.en) the [GPG](https://www.gnupg.org/gph/en/manual/x135.html) signature + checksum of download. If you download over ZeroUP, I've included the official .asc signature files in the bundle where applicable.

Don't trust random binaries that aren't signed. It could very well be script-kiddie malware or nation-state spyware.

1510836718_1KTbtX5zd8hbs9WSe34CUELQgJk8v.body:
Test received. 

Now let's "Get Motivated"....

> Had Thomas Edison not been a man of faith, perseverance and determination, we may still be working by gaslight or at least, it may have been many years before the first electric light was seen. It has been reported that Edison failed over 6,000 times before perfecting the first electric light bulb.
>
>
> On one occasion a young journalist challenged Edison saying to him, "Mr. Edison, why do you keep trying to make light by using electricity when you have failed so many times? Don't you know that gas lights are with us to stay?"
>
>
> To this Edison replied, **"Young man, don't you realize that I have not failed but have successfully discovered six thousand ways that won't work!"**
>
>
> Because Edison believed an electric light was possible, he refused to give up. He tried countless types of material in his search for a filament that would work. He sent men to China, Japan, South America, Asia, Jamaica, Ceylon and Burma to search for fibers to test in his laboratory--all to no avail.
>
>
> On October 21, 1879, after thirteen months of repeated failures, Edison finally succeeded in finding a filament that would work. While experimenting the thought came to him, "Why not try a carbonized cotton fibre?"
>
>
> After going through two spools of cotton, he eventually perfected a strand only to break it while trying to place it in a glass tube. He refused to give up and persevered with this idea for two more days and nights without sleep. Finally he succeeded in placing a carbonized thread into a vacuum-sealed bulb! Eureka! It worked.
>
> **Perseverance pays.**

1512591309_15FBwNYD2411XkJJ1wDSK2HMFNNNF.body:
Great points.

> Over the last year with the explosion of ICO's and Cryptocurrency's, many of which are pointless money grabbers that aim to try to solve null problems or issues

Completely agree. Whenever I here "put it on the block chain" or "raise an ICO!" I just roll my eyes anymore. Commercialization and centralization of otherwise great ideas if used properly.

> True Decentralisation of the DNS system (.bit an area of interest)

OpenNIC is federated, but not fully decentralized. The .bit domains have always been interesting, but cost money and getting Namecoin isn't easy, especially for new users.

> A single currency, with virtual prepaid cards for use within the new decentralised internet solution, removing the need for other tracable methods of payment.

Rather than reinventing the wheel, give Monero or ZCash a try. Both are better privacy wise than BTC.

> A decentralised .bit / custom DNS search engine.

There's [YaCy](http://yacy.net/en/index.html), but the Java overhead is heavy and the results suck.

1512623897_16PUgFapj8pSnEnS1bcAGVRPtfwvQ.body:
For a very basic index, you could use tree or python. tree: > tree -H '.' -L 1 --noreport --charset utf-8 > index.html Or Python: >import os > >'''Create HTML Header''' >html_head = ''' > > > http-equiv="content-type"> > File Archive > > >''' > >'''Create HTML Footer''' >html_end = ''' > > >''' > >def main(): > browseLocal(contents) > > >'''Generate list of files and throw them into div''' >print(html_head) >for file in os.listdir('/path/to/your/files/'): > downloadObj = '
' + '' + file + '' + '
' > print(downloadObj) > print('') >print(html_end) Then: > python index_gen.py > index.html You could spice it up a bit with CSS as well.
